Project administration

[SLO]

In this documentation, we will refer to the project name as <P>, the algorithm name as <A>, and the test set name as <T>. All data that the ALGator system maintains about project <P> is stored in the directory <algator_root>/data_root/projects/PROJ-<P> (where <algator_root> represents the root directory of the ALGator system, pointed to by the environmental variable $ALGATOR_ROOT).

Task List for Project Creation

The following list outlines the tasks that a user of the system must perform to create a new project and define all its components. The list is followed by a more detailed description of each task.

Project

  1. create project (algator.Admin -cp)

Input

  1. define input parameters (algator.Admin -cpa)
  2. define input data (edit the file proj/src/Input.java)
  3. define test case generators (algator.Admin -cgn + edit the file proj/src/TestCaseGenerator_Type<i>.java)
  4. define test set (algator.Admin -ct + edit the files tests/TestSet<i>.json and tests/TestSet<i>.txt)

Output

  1. define output data (edit the file proj/src/Output.java)
  2. define output indicators (algator.Admin -cin + edit the file proj/src/IndicatorTest_<ind>.java)

Algorithm

  1. define algorithm (algator.Admin -ca + edit the file algs/ALG-<alg>/src/Algorithm.java)

All-in-one

  • Shortcut (algator.Admin -call)

Note: with the tasks described in the following we will create the project Sort, input parameters N and DIST, the class Input, generator type Type0, test set TestSet0, the class Output, the indicator Check, and the algorithm JavaSort.

a. Project

Basic configuration files for the project are created with the command algator.Admin -cp

$ java algator.Admin -cp Sort

This generates files as shown in the image below

These created files need to be edited with a text editor, as described further below.

b. Input Parameters

Create input parameters using the command java algator.Admin -cpa
$ java algator.Admin -cpa Sort 
ALGator Admin, version 0.986 (November 2023)

Parameter name: N
Parameter description: Input size
Parameter type [string]: int
Parameter meta [{"Min": 1, "Max": 1, "Step": 1, "Default": 1}]: {"Min":1000, "Max": 1000000000000, "Step":1000, "Default": 5000}
Is this an Input parameter (0 ... false, 1 ... true) [1]: 1

0:Parameter 'N' added to project Sort.
The parameter description is saved in the file proj/testcase.json. The table "InputParameters" lists the names of input parameters, and the table "Parameters" provides detailed descriptions of the parameters (type and range - min, max, and default value). The order in the "InputParameters" table is important, as the parameters will be listed in this order in the output files.

After executing the above command, the file proj/testcase.json contains the entry: 
{
  "Name":        "N",             
  "Description": "Input size", 
  "Type":        "int",
  "Meta":        {"Min":1000, "Max": 1000000000000, "Step":1000, "Default": 5000}      
}
You can also add a parameter directly with the full description (this skips the interactive part, and the parameter is added without additional user intervention):
$ java algator.Admin -cpa Sort '{"Name":"DIST", "Type": "enum", "Meta":{"values":["RND", "SOR", "INV"]}}' '{isInputParameter: true}'

0:Parameter 'DIST' added to project Sort.

c. Input Data

Algorithm's input is defined in the class proj/src/Input.java as a field that holds the input data. The type of the field depends on the type of input data required by algorithm (if the input is an integer array, the field will be of type int[], if the input is a matrix, the attribute will be of type int[][], etc.). For easier management, it is recommended to add a suitable constructor to the Input.java class.

In the project Sort, define the data holder and constructor in the Input.java class like this:

 public int [] arrayToSort;

 public Input(int [] data) {    
    this.arrayToSort = data;
  }

d. Test Case Generators

In the project <P>, create a generator using the command algator.Admin -cgn <P> <type> <params> where <type> is the name (type) of the generator, and <params> is a comma-separated list of generating parameters.
$ java algator.Admin -cgn Sort Type0 N,DIST

This creates the file proj/src/TestCaseGenerator_Type0.java containing the generateTestCase() method, which needs to be appropriately edited (write the missing part of the code so that the generator creates a test case based on the generating parameters).

As mentioned earlier, it is crucial for the generator to set input parameters in addition to the data part. For the default generator (type 0), these values are set automatically, but for other generators, the user must ensure the correct input parameter values.

Example: If a generator of type 1 reads data from a file, in the generateTestCase() method, input parameters should be set using commands like: 
    Variables inputParameters = new Variables();
    inputParameters.addVariable(new EVariable("N", n)); 
    inputParameters.addVariable(new EVariable("DIST", "RND"));
    sortTestCase.getInput().setParameters(inputParameters);

The generator can add additional properties to the input, which will be used for data filtering during analysis. This is done using the addProperty() method, for example:

inputParameters.addProperty(PROPS, "Type", "Type1"); inputParameters.addProperty(PROPS, "Filename", filename);
The generator can use additional (previously created) files for test generation (for example, a test case generator for sorting numbers could read data from the file numbers.rnd). All such files are located in the proj/tests folder and its subfolders. The path to the proj/tests folder in the generator is obtained using the generating parameter TESTS_PATH.

Example: If the generator is given the relative filename in the "Filename" parameter, the full filename is obtained like this: 

    String path     = generatingParameters.getVariable(TESTS_PATH, "").getStringValue();
    String filename = generatingParameters.getVariable("Filename", "").getStringValue();
    String testFile = path + File.separator + filename;

e. Test Sets

Create a test set (i.e., configuration files <T>.json and <T>.txt) using the command algator.Admin -ct <T>,
$ java algator.Admin -ct Sort TestSet1
Then, edit the files TestSet1.json (the most important parameter here is N, which must match the number of test cases) and TestSet1.txt, like this: 
  Type0:test1:1000:RND
  Type0:test2:2000:SOR
  Type0:test3:3000:INV
Based on these files, three test cases with the values of generating parameters (N=1000, DIST=RND), (N=2000, DIST=SOR), and (N=3000, DIST=INV) will be generated. All three test cases will be created by the Type0 generator.

f. Output Data

The algorithm output is represented by the class src/Output.java. The output data section is usually stored in one field. The type of this field depends on the type of output created by the algorithm (if the output is an integer, the field will be of type int, if the output is a string, the field will be of type String, etc.). For easier management, it is recommended to add an appropriate constructor to the Output.java class.

Example: In the Sort project, the data holder and constructor in the Output.java class are defined as follows: 

  public int [] sortedArray;
  
  public Output(int [] data) {
    sortedArray = data;
  }

g. Output Indicators

Add an output indicator to the algorithm using the command algator.Admin -cin.
$ java algator.Admin -cin Sort 
ALGator Admin, version 0.986 (November 2023)

Indicator name: Tmin
Indicator description: Minimal time
Indicator type (string, int, double, timer or counter) [string]: timer
Timer ID [0]: 0
Timer STAT (MIN, MAX, AVG, SUM, FIRST, LAST, ALL or MED) [MIN]: MIN

0:Indicator 'Tmin' added to project Sort.
For non-timer and non-counter indicators this method creates java file (proj/src/IndicatorTest_<ind>.java which sholud be edited, for example, like this: 
  public class IndicatorTest_Check extends AbstractIndicatorTest {

    @Override
    public Object getValue(TestCase testCase, Output algorithmOutput) {
      return Arrays.equals(algorithmOutput.sortedArray, testCase.getExpectedOutput().sortedArray)
               ? "OK" : "NOK";
    }
  }

h. Algorithm for Solving the Given Problem

Create an algorithm using the command algator.Admin -ca
$ java algator.Admin -ca Sort JavaSort
Then, edit the files algs/ALG-JavaSort/algorithm.json and algs/ALG-JavaSort/src/Algorithm.java, like this: 

public class Algorithm extends ProjectAbstractAlgorithm {
  @Override
  protected Output execute(Input input) {
    javaSort(input.arrayToSort);
      
    return new Output(input.arrayToSort);    
  }  
 
  private void javaSort(int[] data) {
    java.util.Arrays.sort(data);
  }
}
In this case, the actual implementation of the algorithm is in the javaSort() method, which takes an array as input and sorts it. The execute() method serves as a bridge between the ALGator system and the algorithm implementation.

Shortcut

We can create the project (with all its components) with one simple command:
$ java algator.Admin -call Sort
To complete the project setup we only have to edit the source files (proj/src/Input.java, proj/src/Output.java, proj/src/TestCaseGenerator_Type0.java, proj/src/IndicatorTest_Check.java, algs/ALG-Alg1/src/Algorithm.java) as described above.
